24. The work is dedicated to M. Junius Brutus (85—42 nc), to whom Cicero also inscribed the Orator, paradoxa, De Finibus, and De Nasum Deorum, and in whose honor he gave the name Brutus to the dialogue Dc (filaris Oratori- bus. Brutus had been trained in philosophy by Cato, his maternal uncle. He adopted, for the most part, the doc- trines ot' Antiochus, the eclectio Academic, and was him- self the author of several philosophical treatises‚ especially works on Virtue, Duty‚ and Patience. Of his ability Cicero (Acad. I. 12) and Quintilian (X. 1. 123) speak in very high terms. Cicero respected the talents and character of his younger contemporary, but, owing to the peculiar dispo- sition of the latter, the two never became very ardent and devoted friends.
